Government incompetence in today's post-9/11 world is a serious 
      matter. That's why correspondent 
      Steve Kroft's lead report on a bungled $24 billion modernization 
      program for the U.S. Coast Guard is so important: the maritime force is 
      responsible for protecting 95,000 miles of shoreline and 361 ports against 
      terrorism. Five years into a project that was supposed to strengthen it by 
      more than 200 ships and boats, the Coast Guard fleet is smaller and less 
      able to perform its mission for the Department of Homeland Security, says 
      the chairman of the congressional committee with Coast Guard oversight. 
      Rep. Elijah Cummings (D-Md.) tells Kroft the program, dubbed "Deepwater," 
      is a "mess." It's a mess because the Coast Guard decided to let a joint 
      venture of defense contractors, which then hired its own companies, manage 
      Deepwater, says the former head of the Coast Guard's Logistics and 
      Engineering Department, retired Capt. Kevin Jarvis. "People say that this 
      is like the fox watching the henhouse and it's worse than that," says 
      Jarvis. "It's where the government asked the fox to develop the security 
      system for the henhouse, then told them 'By the way, we'll give you the 
      security code to the system and we'll tell you when we're on 
      vacation.'"
 
Watch an excerpt of 
      Kroft's report.
 
Our 
      second story is hard to believe, yet advocates for the homeless say it's 
      been going on for years. In fact, it's happened so many times in Los Angeles that 
      cameras have been set up near homeless shelters to catch it on tape, 
      because it's illegal as well as immoral. It's called "hospital dumping." 
      Hospitals put homeless patients in a van or a taxi and drop them on the 
      city's Skid Row, sometimes dressed in only a flimsy gown, even 
      if they're not healthy enough to fend for themselves. CNN's Anderson Cooper reports on one 
      especially egregious case of a paraplegic left off by an uncaring van 
      driver to crawl on his hands in the street. Says Los Angeles City Attorney 
      Rocky Delgadillo, "These may be the perfect victims. Because a homeless 
      individual dumped on skid row disappears into the chaos of skid row within 
      minutes. It's hard for us to find them, and then get the evidence that we 
      need."
 
Watch an excerpt of 
      Cooper's report. 
 
Imagine every child, everywhere, owning a laptop computer. Well, 
      for MIT Prof. Nicholas Negroponte, it is a goal he admits he may not 
      achieve in total, but he's on his way as correspondent Lesley Stahl 
      reports in our third segment. He's raised the money from rich companies 
      like Google and has designed a cheap, child-proof laptop he's testing with 
      kids in places like Brazil. Negroponte thinks his 
      "One Laptop Per Child" project can make a difference, especially in 
      countries where half the kids don't even go to school. "If they don't go 
      to school, this is school in a box," he says. 
 
Watch 
      Stahl's Reporter's Notebook.
